summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of California today announced criminal charges against a Hesperia man accused of stealing a motorized device used to move shipping containers.  According to the SEC's complaint, on May 20, 2018, Hesperia, Tennessee resident Jhyy Demond Chubbuck was arrested and subsequently charged with violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The complaint alleges that Chubsbuck, who was a security guard stationed in the business's office located at the main entrance to the storage yard, used the device to drive around the lot for approximately 10 to 15 minutes before being discovered alone inside the vehicle.  As alleged in the complaint, the device did not qualify as a "vehicle" under the federal securities laws, and the defendant was subsequently sentenced to three years, doubled for the strike prior, and an additional one year for the prison prior, for a total of seven years in state prison.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the complaint in the SEC complaint, defendant consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins him from future violations of the securities laws and orders him to pay a $1,000 civil penalty and a $100,000 officer-and-director bar.  Chubsck also agreed to be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for five years.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Department for the Northern District of Tennessee today announced related criminal charges.   The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.  Investors can quickly and easily check the backgrounds of people selling investments by using theÂ SECÂ institutions.gov website to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals. Â The SEC's Complaint, filed in federal district court in Memphis, Tennessee, alleges that defendant violated Section 10 of the Exchange Act by failing to disclose that he had a prior conviction for a felony that qualified as a strike under federal securities law and that he was prohibited from purchasing or selling any type of motorized equipment in violation of federal law.Â  The SEC also alleges that the defendant violated Sections 1170.12 and 667, subdivisions (a) and (c) and that defendant failed to provide a record sufficient to support a conviction under federal law for a violation of section 10851.
